findings.title: Reentrancy vulnerability
findings.explanation: External call to `_addr.call.value(_wei)` is made before updating the `Holders[_addr]` state, allowing a malicious fallback to re-enter and drain funds

findings.title: Access Control vulnerability
findings.explanation: Public initializer function is unprotected by onlyOwner or constructor, allowing anyone to reinitialize contract state

findings.title: Arithmetic vulnerability
findings.explanation: Unprotected addition on Holders[msg.sender] += msg.value can overflow due to lack of bounds checking

findings.title: Unchecked Low Level Calls vulnerability
findings.explanation: Low-level call operations (`.call`) are used without checking their return values, which can lead to silent failures.

findings.title: Denial Of Service vulnerability
findings.explanation: External calls are made (token.call and _addr.call.value) without checking the return value, and holder balances are cleared or decremented regardless of success, potentially locking funds if the calls fail.

findings.title: Short Addresses vulnerability
findings.explanation: Public function uses token.call(...) with address and uint parameters but does not validate msg.data length, allowing a short address attack.

findings.title: Other vulnerability
findings.explanation: The function initTokenBank is intended as a constructor but its name does not match the contract name (TokenBank), so it is a public function that anyone can call to reset the owner and MinDeposit values.

vulnerability_location.description: External call to `_addr.call.value(_wei)` is made before updating the `Holders[_addr]` state, allowing a malicious fallback to re-enter and drain funds
Public initializer function is unprotected by onlyOwner or constructor, allowing anyone to reinitialize contract state
Unprotected addition on Holders[msg.sender] += msg.value can overflow due to lack of bounds checking
Low-level call operations (`.call`) are used without checking their return values, which can lead to silent failures.

External calls are made (token.call and _addr.call.value) without checking the return value, and holder balances are cleared or decremented regardless of success, potentially locking funds if the calls fail.
Public function uses token.call(...) with address and uint parameters but does not validate msg.data length, allowing a short address attack.

The function initTokenBank is intended as a constructor but its name does not match the contract name (TokenBank), so it is a public function that anyone can call to reset the owner and MinDeposit values.
